Based on my search results, here's what I found about Pride and Prejudice TikTok BookTok trends for 2024-2025 and its impact on young readers and Gen Z:

## Pride and Prejudice's BookTok Revival

Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen won the "best BookTok revival" category in recent awards, highlighting its significant resurgence on the platform. Media specialists have noted "an uptick in classics like Pride and Prejudice" becoming wildly requested among BookTok users.

The surprise lies in BookTok's selection, often geared toward the rediscovery of great classics: from Pride and Prejudice to contemporary works, showing how the platform bridges classic and modern literature.

## Impact on Young Readers and Gen Z

Successful BookTok posts have the ability to rekindle an appreciation of books in young readers, particularly Gen Z. In fact, 62% of TikTok users from the US have read at least one book based on BookTok recommendations and 48% of users read more books overall than prior to the discovery of BookTok.

As of 2023, BookTok is particularly popular with Generation Z users, people who were born between 1996 and 2010. The main demographic of BookTok creators, viewers and authors is young women.

## 2024-2025 Trends and Publishing Impact

TikTok's parent company ByteDance announced plans to publish 10 to 15 printed books annually, starting in 2025. The genres include romantasy, romantic novels, slow-burn love stories, the classic teen drama "Enemies to lovers", and young adult fiction, the most popular among Gen Z.

The BookTok hashtag is reported to have over 107 billion views globally, while other sources cite over 181.7 billion viewers and 28.6M hashtag views, demonstrating the platform's massive reach.

## How BookTok Works

Content creators often organize their recommendations around tropes and aesthetics which readers are already familiar with. The most popular genres on BookTok — fantasy and romance, which, combined, have been newly termed "romantasy".

BookTok favors "convincing you to read books based on their aesthetics", which might appear a shallow way to read but it is clearly very compelling, especially for a generation for whom countercultures have given way to microtrends and niche aesthetic identities.

The revival of Pride and Prejudice on BookTok represents a broader trend of young readers discovering classic literature through social media, transforming how traditional works reach new audiences in the digital age.
